Ye polish'd arts, that o'er the human mind</br>Too often triumph with seductive sway,</br>From this lone solitude the pangs unkind</br>Of rude and restless sorrow chace away.</br>From heaven ye sprung, from heaven's eternal ray,</br>And heavenly the commission that ye bear;</br>Here then your angel-offices display,</br>And sooth each bitter thought, each wild and busy care.

Oh!  turn from them, the idle and the vain,</br>From them, the base, the selfish, and the proud;</br>Your gentler recompence and nobler gain</br>Not the applauding tumult of the crowd,</br>But oh!  to scatter the tempestuous cloud</br>Of mortal griefs, to blunt affection's dart,</br>And, sweetly, from the cradle to the shroud,</br>Soften's life's rugged doom, and meliorate the heart.

Visit, ye Muses!  with celestial aid</br>This humble spot, and lighten my sad hours;</br>For well ye love the silence of the shade,</br>And pleasant woods where leafy grandeur lours;</br>And here are groves, and fields, and fragrant flowers,</br>And bubbling brooks that gently murmur near—</br>Oh!  live for ever in these happy bowers,</br>And shed your purest joys, your holiest blessings here!</br>
